On Feb. 23, 2019: A small protest took place in front of the embassy of Venezuela in Sofia in support of President Maduro. Citizens carries posters reading 'USA, leave Venezuela alone,' expressing the beliefs of protesters that the crisis in Venezuela was caused by the USA.
On Feb. 23, 2019: Lawyers protested in Sofia against a contradictory agreement about professional ethics.

On Feb. 19, 2019: Residents of Kyustendil protested for a second day in front of the police directorate in their town against the killing of a Bulgarian man by an ethnic Roma man which resulted from a fight at a bar on Sunday. Protesters demanded stricter control in the Roma neighborhood Iztok. Police said the killing was a result of the use of alcohol and not ethnic tension.

On Feb. 18, 2019: Residents of Kyustendil organized a peaceful protest in their town against the killing of a Bulgarian man by an ethnic Roma man which resulted from a fight at a bar on the previous day. Protesters expressed support for the family of the deceased.

On Feb. 17, 2019: Residents of the Sofia neighborhood Gorublyane blocked Tsarigradsko shose boulevard in both directions towards the exit for Plovdiv, protesting against what they perceived was discrimination against low-rise neighborhoods. Protesters complained of the lack of playgrounds, sewerage, sidewalks, and public transport in Gorublyane.

On Feb, 16, 2019: Hundreds of Bulgarians organized Lukov March to commemorate the death of Nazi General Hristo Lukov. The demonstrators marched from the National Palace of Culture to the home of General Lukov on Trakia street. Police guarded the protesters. Earlier on the same day, there was a counter-protest against the Lukov March, racial hate and neo-Nazi ideology in the city center in Sofia.

On Feb. 9, 2019: Residents of the village of Voyvodinovo, Plovdiv went on a demonstration after they found out some of the Romani who lived in illegal houses had returned and tried to settle in. About 50 demonstrators tried to break off a police cordon guarding the Roma neighborhood. No injuries were reported. Later, police escorted the Romani out of the neighborhood.

On Feb. 4, 2019: People with disabilities and their families protested in front of the Ministry of Health in Sofia against the new way of determining disability grade, based on a leading illness and not on the combination of all health problems. Protesters were worried this would deprive them of their rights to proper health services and pensions.

On Feb. 2, 2019: Residents of Kazanlak protested against wagons, normally driven by the poor and ethnic Romani population in their town. Protesters demanded wagons to be banned on roads due to the many traffic incidents they caused and blamed the government for not taking action on the issue.

On Feb. 1, 2019: Citizens protested in Gabrovo against the construction of a detour road, situated in close proximity to their homes. Some complained of excessive noise and that they found construction leftovers in their backyards.

On Feb. 1, 2019: Residents of the villages of Beli Bryag and Troyanovo protested in front of Parliament in Sofia against the effects of the 30-year concession awarded to the company 'Mini Maritsa-Iztok', which would lead to the 'extinction' of the two villages. Protesters complained that they had to sell their houses, but 'Mini Martisa-Iztok' was buying them at below-market prices.

On Jan. 28, 2019: Ecoactivists and citizens protested in front of the Council of Ministers in Sofia against construction works taking place on Bulgarian mountains and at the seaside, which they deemed illegal. The protesters demanded government to enforce stricter accountability over issuing construction permits and to start new proposals and competitions for construction projects.

On Jan. 27, 2019: Citizens from the Romani Stolipinovo neighborhood in Plovdiv and police clashed after a police raid, which lead to the arrest of four Roma drug dealers. Roma people from the neighborhood went out of their houses after they saw the arrests and tensions escalated. No injuries were reported, but some of the residents said police officers were violent and threw bottles at them.

On Jan. 27, 2019: Citizens from Vidin protested demanding the speeding up of construction works of a highway leading to Sofia. The protesters gathered in front of the Vidin Mayor's residence and made a snowman, at which they threw tomatoes and eggs. They blamed the Mayor for intentionally slowing down construction works.
On Jan. 26, 2019: Skateboarders protested at the subway underpass below the National Palace of Culture (NDK) in Sofia against the recent police ban to skateboard in the NDK garden.

On Jan. 25, 2019: Health workers from the Plovdiv Municipal Hospital 'St. Mina' protested in front of the municipality building in Plodviv. The reason for their dissatisfaction was their low salaries and the lack of funds for their increase. More than 30 nurses had resigned collectively from the beginning of the year.

On Jan. 24, 2019: Ecoactivists gathered in front of the Council of Ministers in Sofia to demand the resignation of Minister of the Environment and Water Neno Dimov. The protesters were dissatisfied that Dimov allowed construction and tree cutting on protected areas in the Pirin National Park.

On Jan. 23, 2019: Health workers and their supporters organized a silent protest in front of the hospital in Gorna Oryahovitsa denouncing the recent violence against hospital staff by patients. Recent cases included a woman who came with her infant and hit a nurse with a phone, patients who broke the door of the hospital, and a man who was violent and tried to commit suicide. The protesting health workers threatened with collective resignation.

On Jan. 19, 2019: Residents of several villages in Shumen organized a protest against national road taxes, which they deemed to be too expensive and not appropriate for the roads in their municipality.

On Jan. 18, 2019: Police in Bulgaria disrupted a suspected terrorism financing ring and detained 43 people in raids across the country. The prosecution pressed charges against six of them for preparing terrorist attacks. One of the suspects was a Syrian citizen permanently residing in Bulgaria who, according to the police, transferred money abroad to international extremist groups.

On Jan. 16, 2019: Ecoactivists gathered in front of the Council of Ministers in Sofia to celebrate the government's decision to stop plans for the expansion of the Bansko ski resort, which they had demanded and protested for. The activists called for the resignation of the Minister of Environment and water resources Neno Dimov.

On Jan. 15, 2019: Residents of Troyan protested in their town demanding the Roma neighborhood to be demolished due to what they claimed were illegally built houses and the illegal consumption of water and electricity by the Roma residents. Protesters also compained about burning of cable and other rubber objects, unpleasant smells, and homeless animals like horses and dogs walking around.

On Jan. 14, 2019: About 200 ethnic Roma citizens protested in front of the Council of Ministers in Sofia demanding the resignation of Minister of Defense Krasimir Karakachanov over his insulting comment that 'gypsies have become very arrogant.' Protesters condemned the demolition of illegal houses in the Roma neighborhood in Voyvodinovo, where two Roma men beat up a military man the previous week.

On Jan. 14, 2019: Entrepreneurs and their employees protested in front of th EVN building in Plovdiv against the planned increase of 37% in electricity prices for businesses, saying it would lead to losing jobs and very high costs.

On Jan. 11, 2019: About 200-500 people protested in the village of Voyvodinovo, Plovdiv for a fifth consecutive day against the illegal houses of the Roma population, demanding them to move away, days after two Roma men beat up an officer from the Special Forces. Present and formers military officers joined the protest in solidarity with their colleague, carrying Bulgarian flags and shouting nationalist slogans like 'Freedom or Death' and 'Bulgarians are heroes.'

On Jan. 10, 2019: Citizens from the village of Voyvodinovo, Plovdiv, protested against the illegal houses of the Roma population, demanding them to move away, days after two Roma men beat up an officer from the Special Forces. Several illegal houses had already been demolished, as ordered by the local administration.
On Jan. 10, 2019: Roma people gathered in front of the hospital in Sofia to protest against the hospital's inadequate emergency response which resulted in a child's death.

On Jan. 9, 2019: Citizens from the village of Voyvodinovo, Plovdiv, protested against the illegal houses of the Roma population, demanding them to move away, days after two Roma men beat up an officer from the Special Forces. On Jan. 8, 2019: Citizens from the village of Voyvodinovo, Plovdiv, protested against the illegal houses of the Roma population, demanding them to move away, two days after two Roma men beat up an officer from the Special Forces. On Jan. 7, 2019: About 200 people from the village of Voyvodino, Plovdiv protested in relation to the attacked man by Romani the previous day. Protesters demanded the mayor to demolish the houses of the Roma in the village, which they claimed to be illegal, and accused the local government of patronizing the Roma population and not taking care of law and order in the village.

On Jan. 6, 2019: Two Romani men insulted and beat up a man who worked at the Special Force unit after he advised them not to walk on the road and disrupt the vehicle traffic in the village of Voyvodino, Plovdiv. The man suffered from concussion and multiple head wounds.

Bulgarian and Ukranian citizens protested against Russia's aggressive policy and waved a Ukranian flag. The Christmas tree was a present from Russia, which some Bulgarians did not like and the website of the Russian embassy shared a post calling the disapproving Sofianites 'retards.'

Bulgarian Transport Minister Ivaylo Moskovski responded that the row between Bulgaria and Libya over the detained vessel is merely a 'private legal matter.'

On Oct. 24, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities and other Bulgarian citizens protested outside the district administration in Pleven demanding the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Valeri Simeonov over insulting comments and inadequate behavior.
On Oct. 23, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities in Varna demonstrated insisting on the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Valeri Simeonov over his insulting words.
On Oct. 23, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities in Vidin demonstrated insisting on the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Valeri Simeonov over his insulting words.

On Oct. 23, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities and other Bulgarian citizens protested outside the building of the Council of Ministers demanding the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Valeri Simeonov over insulting comments and inadequate behavior.

On Oct. 23, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities and other Bulgarian citizens protested in Dobrich demanding the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Valeri Simeonov over insulting comments and inadequate behavior and demanding social policy reform.

On Oct. 23, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities and other Bulgarian citizens protested outside the district administration in Silistra demanding the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Valeri Simeonov over insulting comments and inadequate behavior.
On Oct. 22, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities in Varna demonstrated insisting on the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Valeri Simeonov over his insulting words.
On Oct. 22, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities in Vidin demonstrated insisting on the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Valeri Simeonov over his insulting words.

On Oct. 22, 2018: Hundreds of Bulgarian citizens protested together with mothers of children with disabilities demanding the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Valeri Simeonov, who called them'noisy women with allegedly sick children.'

On Oct. 22, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities and other Bulgarian citizens protested outside the district administration in Silistra demanding the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Valeri Simeonov over insulting comments and inadequate behavior.

On Oct. 21, 2018: Residents of different Sofia neighborhoods blocked the ring road around Sofia protesting because they believed they were discriminated in paying higher garbage fees than residents in more central neighborhoods.
On Oct. 20, 2018: Citizens in Pleven organized a march against human trafficking to mark the European Day for Combating Trafficking in Human Beings.
On Oct. 19, 2018: Citizens of two villages in Silistra blocked the road connecting Silistra and Ruse to protest against the bad road condition and the lack of renovation works.
On Oct. 17, 2018: Pensioners went on a protest in front of the Council of Ministers in Sofia demanding a rise in pensions from July 1, 2019.
On Oct. 10, 2018: Protesters in Ruse gathered in front of the city hall to demand better air quality and stricter control of domestic air pollution.
On Oct. 10, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities protested in front of the District Administration in Silistra, demanding reforms in social legislation.

Oct. 10-11, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities camped in tents in front of the Council of Ministers' Building in Sofia before Thursday's discussion on the People with Disabilities Bill by the National Council for Integration of People with Disabilities. The protesters aimed to demonstrate that they will not give up on their requests on full reform.
On Oct. 8, 2018: Citizens from Ruse protested demanding a fair trial for a man who hit an 18-year-old man from the village of Byala, which led the latter's death.
On Oct. 7 or 8, 2018: Citizens organized a protest in Sofia against the bad renovation works on the 'Graf Ignatiev' street, one of the busiest streets in Sofia.

On Oct. 5, 2018: Around 200 people protested outside the municipal building in Sofia against bad renovation works in the city center on 'Graf Ignatiev' street. Protesters tried to enter the municipality, but were stopped by the guards.

On Oct. 5, 2018: Hundreds of residents from five villages in the Plovdiv municipality blocked the ring road leading to Plovdiv, protesting against the expansion of a marble mine near the village of Belashtitsa. Protesters demanded the contract for the operation of the mine to be suspended in 2021.

On Oct. 4, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities protested demanding social reform and were admitted to have a dialogue with MPs in Parliament in Sofia. The protesters were disappointed by the legislative progress and all of them left Parliament, some crying.

On Oct. 2, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities organized a protest march in Sofia under the slogan 'The systems is killing us.' The protest took place because the MPs did not meet the October 1 deadline for voting on at least one of the three draft laws regarding people with disabilities, personal assistance and social services.
On Sept. 25, 2018: About 100 citizens from Razgrad gathered on Vazrazhdane square in their town to protest against the air pollution evident from the bad air smell.
On Sept. 25, 2018: Hunters protested at the Danube Bridge crossing point near Ruse against the ban on group hunting of wild bore, ordered by the Bulgarian Ministry of agriculture, food and forests.
On Sept. 22, 2018: Residents of the Sofia neighborhood 'Gorublyane' protested against the municipality's plan to build a park on the land of their fathers and grandfathers.

On Sept. 22, 2018: Employees from the wine producing factory Vinprom Karnobat protested for a second day due to the closing of three factories and threatened to strike. The factories were closed by customs due to violation of tax laws.

On Sept. 21, 2018: Employees from the wine producing factory Vinprom Karnobat demonstrated due to the closing of three factories and threatened to strike. Demonstrators attacked customs officers. Police intervened and no serious injuries were reported.
On Sept. 17, 2018: About 100 citizens protested in front of Parliament in Sofia demanding the government to resign. The protest was organized by Bulgarians living and working abroad.

On Sept. 16, 2018: An antigovernment protest of a few hundred people took place in front of the Council of Ministers in Sofia. Protesters demanded the government to resign and a radical change in the political system in Bulgaria to be implemented. Several protesters tried to enter the Council but did not manage. No clashes were reported.

On Sept. 16, 2018: About 200 citizens protested in front of the Palace of Justice in Sofia in defense of the two arrested Bulgarian and Romanian investigative journalists working on a story about abuse of EU funds.

On Sept. 12, 2018: More than 500 people protested in front of the government building in Varna due to the tragic death of a ballet dancer who was run over by a 25-year-old driver without a license. The protesters demanded the driver to be detained until the trial against him would begin.

On Sept. 10, 2018: Parents protested in front of the municipal building in Sofia due to the lack of free places for their children in daycare. Protesters said that 5000 children were left without a place in nurseries and around 2000 - in daycare, and demanded the appointment of additional staff for daycare institutions operating at full capacity.
On Sept. 9, 2018: Citizens of the village of Raduil, Samokov blocked the Borotvets-Raduil road to protest the bad condition of roads leading to their village.

On Sept. 4, 2018: Seven supporters of the striking dissident Nikolay Kolev 'the Shoeless' entered in the Ministry of Transport in Sofia and tried to arrest the Deputy Minister who was suspected of involvement in a conflict of interest regarding driving schools and the issuing of illegal drivers' license documents. The demonstrators reached the first floor but were accompanied out by police officers.

On Sept. 4, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities put up tents in Radomir, thus joining the protest camps in Sofia. The protesters demanded social reform which would allow better lives for the people with disabilities in Bulgaria.

On Sept. 4, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities put up tents in Razgrad, thus joining the protest camps in Sofia. The protesters demanded social reform which would allow better lives for the people with disabilities in Bulgaria.

On Sept. 4, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities put up tents in front of the municipal government building in Vidin, thus joining the protest camps in Sofia. The protesters demanded social reform which would allow better lives for the people with disabilities in Bulgaria.

On September 1, 2018: Residents of Bozhurishte protested in support of their fellow citizen Grigor Grigorov, who drove the bus that crashed in Svoge on August 25 resulting in the death of 17 people. The protesters demanded transparent case and blamed the government for the bad maintanance of the transportation network in Bulgaria.

On August 29, 2018: Citizens staged a peaceful protest in Ruse demanding a fair trial for the killing of an 18-year-old man from Byala village. The man died after another man hit him while going out of a club and could not wake up from his coma.

On August 29, 2018: Meteorologists from the National Institut of Meteorology and Hydrology protested in Sofia against the insufficient funding of their department. Protesters spoke of unfair treatment on behalf of their leading organization - the Bulgarian Academy of Science.

On August 29, 2018: The residents of Svoge municipality protested demanding the repair of the asphalt pavement in the road section where a bus overturned on August 25, killing 17 and injuring 21 people. Protesters blocked the road where the accident occurred.

On August 27, 2018: Residents of the Sofia neighborhood Ovcha Kupel went on a protest against overdevelopment in their neighbordood. The protesters declared they were against construction and development in the green spaces and sites planned for schools, kindergartens and parking lots.

On August 27, 2018: The residents of Svoge municipality protested demanding the repair of the asphalt pavement in the road section where a bus overturned on August 25, killing 17 and injuring 21. Protesters blocked the road where the accident occurred.

On August 26, 2018: The residents of Svoge municipality protested demanding the repair of the asphalt pavement in the road section where a bus overturned on August 25, killing 17 and injuring 21. Protesters blocked the road where the accident occurred.

On August 24, 2018: Residents of Chepelare blocked the road connecting Smolyan and Plovdiv protesting against the closing of a regional prosecution office in their town. The protesters said the decision did not take their needs into account and could hurt their human rights.
On August 19, 2018: Residents from the municipality of Stara Zagora protested against the development of a limestone quarry in their municipality.

On August 13, 2018: Supporters of the prosecuted for corruption mayor of the Mladost district Desislava Ivancheva protested in front of the Council of Ministers in Sofia. The protesters demanded her release and an independent investigation of organized crime in Bulgaria.
On August 13, 2018: Citizens from Karlovo and municipal villages protested against the closing of the obstetric-gynecological department of the hospital in Karlovo due to the lack of staff.

On August 10, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities resumed their protests after a working group tried to prepare a law for people with disabilities, which the protesting mothers did not like. The protesters set up a tent camp in front of the Ministry of Labor and Social Policy in Sofia.

On August 10, 2018: Animal breeders and farmers from the yambol region protested against the decision of the Bulgarian Food Safety Agency to ban the sale of milk and meat due to animal plague. The protesters complained of the big losses they incurred.

On July 30, 2018: Over a thousand Bulgarians organized a national protest in Sofia against the government's lack of engagement with the needs of people with disabilities under the slogan 'The System is Killing Us - All.' A father shortly left his disabled child at the reception of the Council of Ministers symbolically at the care of government to show the difficult lives of families with disabilities.

On July 24, 2018: Residents from eight villages in Dobrich municipality protested on the road connecting Dobrich and Silistra demanding a full repair of a third-grade road which was in a very bad condition and hindered the transportation of harvest.
On July 23, 2018: Hundreds of farmers protested in Sofia against a mass slaughter of livestock, prompted by an outbreak of ovine rinderpest which was found at a farm close to the border with Turkey.

On July 18, 2018: Hundreds of livestock breeders and farmers protested in front of the Council of Ministers in Sofia against the inappropriate compensation for their slaughtered animals in the Strandzha region, prompted by an outbreak of ovine rinderpest. The protesters spilled milk and burned wool as a sign of protest and blamed the government for inefficiency handling the epidemic.

Reported on 17 July. Farmers joined by BSP party leader protested against euthanising animals after the EU imposed strict measures on July 5 to prevent a livestock disease from spreading in the Strandzha nature area near Malko Tarnovo. No violence was reported.
On July 16, 2018: A protest against euthanasia of healthy animals and in support of the breeders in Strandzha was held in front of the presidency in Sofia.
On July 16, 2018: Residents of the Mladost neighborhood organized a protest against a new construction of a seven-floor building which would be built where a park for children was.

On July 15, 2018: Farmers in the village of Sharkovo, Yambol protested against the slaughter of livestock, prompted by an outbreak of ovine rinderpest which was found at a farm close to the border with Turkey. The leader of the Socialist Party, Kornelia Ninova led the protest, demanding documentation and laboratory tests proving that the animals needed to be killed.

On July 13, 2018: About 500 farmers and their sheep blocked the road in the village fo Sheremetya, Veliko Tarnovo and spilled galons of milk and burned sacks of wool. The protesters demanded resignation of the Minister of Agriculture and more financial aid due to the very low milk prices, which would lead to their bankruptcy.
On July 11, 2018: Doctors from a hospital in Vratsa protested due to unpaid salaries and demanded the hospital to be renovated despite its bad financial condition.
On July 11, 2018: Employees of the Bulgarian National Radio protested in Sofia against the lack of budget transparency and their low salaries.

On July 6, 2018: About 100 citizens protested in front of the Parliament in Sofia in support of the protester Nikolay Kolev 'The Shoeless', who denounced corrpution in the transport sector, especially in the issuing of driver's license documents.

On July 6, 2018: Residents from the village of Brestovene, Razgrad protested by blocking the road towards Ostrovo village due to the unpleasant smells from a local dairy farm, which resulted from inefficient waste management.

On July 6, 2018: Residents from the Sofia neighborhood Gorublyane protested against the construction of park 'Iztok' in the Mladost neighborhood, fearing that the project was a corrupt affair. The protesters said the park could be built on municipal lands instead of private ones, which would allow less funds to be spent on compensating the private proprietors.

On July 5, 2018: Dozens of demonstrators gathered in support of the hunger strike of Nikolay Kolev 'The Shoeless' in front of the National Assembly in Sofia. They formed a chain at the entrance and demanded that the MPs meet him. After brief clash with the police, the chain of demonstrators was moved.

On July 4, 2018: Citizens protested in front of the Presidency in Sofia against the restart of the nuclear power plant Belene. Counterprotesters organized by ABC were also demonstrating and talked about the benefits of the restart of the plant.

On July 4, 2018: About 27 civil society organizations and their supporters protested in front of the Council of Ministers in Sofia against various social, environmental and economic issues happening in Bulgaria, such as construction destroying nature preserves and lack of government funding for cancer patients.

On July 4, 2018: Citizens from the Vladaya neighborhood in Sofia blocked the road connecting Pernik and Sofia to protest against its renovation, which they thought was badly done. Protesters emphasized this road was one of the busiest in the country.

On July 4, 2018: Small-scale fuel merchants protested in front of the Council of Ministers in Sofia against a proposed law, which would require them to block a certain sum of money as a bank guarantee.
On July 2, 2018: People suffering from reumatism protested in Sofia demanding their compulsory doctor visits to be scheduled in the towns and cities they live, not only in Sofia.

On June 27, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities staged a silent protest in front of the National Palace of Culture in Sofia before a meeting of the European Presidency in the building. The protesters wanted to show how nobody discussed the problems and difficulties of people with disabilities in Bulgaria.

On June 26, 2018: Small gas station owners and fuel merchants protested in from of the Parliament in Sofia. The protesters were worried about a proposed law, which would require them to block a certain sum of money as a bank guarantee and emphasized they did not want to be treated as large fuel businesses.

On June 25, 2018: Around 250 buses from around the country and about 50 heavy trucks participated in the national protest in Sofia against the prepared bill for the establishment of a Bulgarian Automobile Chamber. According to the protesters, the Chamber would not solve the problems in their sector.

On June 21, 2018: Meteorologists organized a peaceful protest in Sofia against the leadership of the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, which they said was attempting to take funding away and close the meteorological department.

On June 19, 2018: Tens of citizens protested in Aheloy against the new road towards the seaside resort Sunny Beach, which was operational the previous week. Protesters said there was no detour leading to their town, which they deemed necessary as a lot of them worked in Sunny beach.

On June 18, 2018: Parents of children with disabilities set up a tent camp in Ruse starting a continuous protest with the demand for social reform to help their children live better lives and take their individual needs into account.
On June 17, 2018: Representatives of various nature protection groups protested in Sofia, expressing discontent at construction projects around the country which would harm protected areas.
On June 14, 2018: Citizens protested in Sofia fearing that the newly discovered Roman archaeological site in Pokrovnik, Blagoevgrad would be destroyed due to construction of the Struma highway.
Bulgarian News Agency; Xinhua; Balkan Insight

On June 11, 2018: Around 4,000 LGBTI persons took part in Sofia Pride, demonstrating under the motto 'Different People, Equal Rights!', which aimed at bringing in public focus achieving equality for the LGBTI people. Security forces were deployed due to last years' clashes with opponents of LGBTI people.

On June 7, 2018: Around 150 people, organized by the coalition Democratic Bulgaria, protested outside the Parliament against the government, the opposition, and their plan to restart the Belene nuclear power plant. The protesters shouted'Resign' and 'Theft' and said that the decision for Belene was appealed in the court.

On June 6, 2018: Around 300 citizens protested outside the Parliament in Sofia against the restart of Belene nuclear power plant and chanted 'Resignation' for the government. The demonstration was organized by the recently formed right-wing Democratic Bulgaria formation.

On June 6, 2018: Parents of children with disabilities set up a tent camp in Dobrich, starting a continuous protest with the demand for social reform to help their children live better lives and take their individual needs into account.

On June 5, 2018: Growers of cherries from Stara Zagora protested against low purchase prices. They gathered at the Stara Zagora road junction on the Trakia highway and poured a few boxes of fruit on the ground.
On June 3, 2018: Parents protested in Burgas against compulsory vaccination of their children on the International Vaccine Injury Awareness Day.
On June 3, 2018: Parents protested in Ruse against compulsory vaccination of their children on the International Vaccine Injury Awareness Day.
On June 3, 2018: Parents protested in Varna against compulsory vaccination of their children on the International Vaccine Injury Awareness Day.

On June 3, 2018: Parents of children with disabilities continued their protest after they set up a tent camp outside the Parliament in Sofia. The protesters demanded better social reforms, which would integrate people with disabilities in the society.
On June 3, 2018: Parents protested in front of Parliament in Sofia against compulsory vaccination of their children on the International Vaccine Injury Awareness Day.

On June 2, 2018: Parents of children with disabilities continued their protest after they set up a tent camp outside the Parliament in Sofia. The protesters demanded better social reforms, which would integrate people with disabilities in the society.
On June 1, 2018: Parents started open-ended protests and set up tent camps in front of Parliament in Sofia to demonstrate against the state's social policy.

On May 29, 2018: People with lung diseases and their supporters protested in front of the Ministry of Health in Sofia due to their discontinued access to lung transplants. The protesters expressed discontent at the unavailability of such operations in Bulgaria and the inefficiency and lack of care on behalf of the health institutions in Bulgaria.

On May 28, 2018: Citizens protested in the center of Sofia against the construction of a waste burning site in Sofia. The objective of the project would be to reduce both fine particulate and carbon emissions, but residents in the area were worried about air pollution.
On May 27, 2018: Hospital workers from Lovech blocked the road connecting Sofia and Varna, demanding information regarding the future of their hospital, which was in unstable financial condition.

On May 24, 2018: Residents from Garmen protested peacefully demanding the government to tear down the illegal houses in which the Roma population lived. The protesters also marked a three year anniversary of the big fight between Bulgarians and Roma in the village.

On May 22, 2018: The opposition coalition Democratic Bulgaria organized a protest in Sofia, demanding the government to stop the planned renewal of the Belene nuclear power plant and resignation of the ruling coalition. Representatives from Alternative for Bulgarian Revival counterprotested, supporting the nuclear plant's renewal.

On May 20, 2018: A group of rose growers protested in Kazanlak in the Rose valley, scattering rose petals on the roads to protest the crash of the rose petal prices, which threatened their livelihood.

On May 19, 2018: Citizens of the Sofia neighborhood Vladaya went out on a protest on the road connecting Sofia and Pernik, expressing their discontent at the bad renovation of the busy road connecting the cities.
On May 18, 2018: Rose producers blocked the road to Rozino village and Banya town, protesting because of the drastic decline in the purchase price of their roses.
On May 17, 2018: Truck drivers gathered at the border crossing with Romania 'Danube Bridge' to express their discontent at the 'Macron' law for EU mobility, which would harm their businesses.

On May 17, 2018: Truck drivers organized a truck procession in Sofia, which ended with a demonstration in front of the National Palace of Culture. The drivers expressed their discontent at the 'Macron' law for EU mobility, which would harm their businesses.

On May 16, 2018: Citizens protested in front of the Orthodox palace in Sofia against the Orthodox church's decision not to send a delegation in Macedonia to commemorate the 100 year anniversary of the Archdiocese of Ohrid.

On May 14, 2018: Family members and friends of the murdered 11-year-old Nikol gathered in front of the courthouse in Burgas during the trial of her killer. The group gathered peacefully, demanding a fair trial.
On May 14, 2018: Residents of the villages Pancharevo, Kokalyane and Bistritsa protested demanding sewerage and better infrastructure on the streets.
On May 14, 2018: Citizens gathered at the exit of Silistra to protest the passing of big trucks through their city, which caused traffic jams.

On May 14, 2018: Doctors and nurses from the Vratsa hospital demonstrated because of their three-month wage delay. The rioters threw eggs at Deputy Minister of Health Zheni Nacheva, who arrived today in Vratsa to present the new director of the hospital.

On May 12, 2018: On International Nurses Day, healthcare specialists protested in Sofia. They demonstrated against the shortage of employees, the lack of young specialists in the healthcare system, low salaries, and the insufficient opportunities for continuing education and career development.

On May 11, 2018: Residents of the Dianabad neighborhood protested in Sofia against planned construction in the space between their residential buildings and the destruction of green space used for recreation.
On 10 May, people with disabilities protested in Sofia against a new law regarding individual diagnosis which they deemed would deprive them of sufficient personal assistance. [size=no report]
On May 7, 2018: Pro-vegan activists protested in Sofia against the consumption of meat products in Sofia by removing their clothes, sprayed with fake blood and wrapped in plastic bags.

On May 4, 2018: Citizens protested in Blagoevgrad in the defense of the newly found archaelogical site near the village Pokrovnik. Protesters feared the site would be destroyed due to the construction of the new highway, which was the reason it had been discovered.

On May 2, 2018: Tens of parents protested in front of the government buildings in Sofia, demanding more adequate care and support for the children with disabilities and a dialogue with the MPs, who did not show up.

On May 1, 2018: The Bulgarian Socialist party held its annual celebration of the 1st May (Socialist day of labor), which ended with a peaceful protest outside the governmental buildings in Sofia. The party members criticized the government and called for snap elections.

On May 1, 2018: Residents of the village Sinemorets, Tsarevo municipality, gathered to protest planned construction which would, in their opinion, ruin one of the few preserved natural beaches on the Black Sea.

On Apr. 29, 2018: Citizens from Kubrat protested at the exit of the town blocking the road connecting Ruse and Razgrad. They protested against the bad condition of the road and said they were buried alive without roads.
On Apr. 26, 2018: Residents from the Sofia neighborhood Lozenetz protested against the construction of a tall building which they deemed was illegal.

On Apr. 23, 2018: Musicians from the Bulgarian National Radio protested in Sofia complaining of their low income. On the same day, employees from the regional health inspectorate in Sofia organized a protest in front of the Council of Ministers to demand higher salaries and change of labor regulations, according to which, they could not receive a raise.

On Apr. 22, 2018: Ecoactivists protested in Sofia against planned construction at the camping site Koral and the new architecture plan in Tsarevo, which would include development on 83 hectares of nature park Strandzha.

On Apr. 21, 2018: A dozen of citizens protested in Sofia against the controversial arrest of Dessislava Ivancheva, mayor of Sofia's Mladost district, and her deputy Bilyana Petrova for taking a bribe.

On Apr. 18, 2018: Mothers of children with disabilities protested in Sofia demanding social reform to address their needs. The protesters put a skeleton in a wheelchair, symbolizing the state killing their children. The mothers insisted to enter the Council of Ministers to discuss their issues but were denied entrance.

On Jan. 17, 2018: Students, teachers and parents from several schools in Sliven protested in front of the school premises against the new education reform, which would require to close and then open schools, a complicated and unnecessary step according to the protesters.
On April 12, 2018: Citizens from four villages in the Pleven region blocked a road towards the port Somovit, protesting against the bad condition of roads.

On Apr. 12, 2018: Citizens protested in front of the Palace of Justice in Sofia in support of Zhelyaz Andreev, who was accused of breaking the embargo between the USA and Syria, while working at a call center in Sofia. Andreev said he was innocent and that he did not know about the embargo.
On Apr. 11, 2018: Citizens with disabilities or with a family member with disability protested in Dobrich demanding better social reforms to address their needs.
On Apr. 11, 2018: Citizens with disabilities or with a family member with disability protested in Shumen demanding better social reforms to address their needs.
On Apr. 11, 2018: Thousands of citizens with disabilities or with a family member with disability protested in Sofia demanding better social reforms to address their needs.

On Apr. 10, 2018: Protesters in Sofia welcomed EU environmental ministers and the EU environment commissioner Karmenu Vella with a protest against a controversial development plan for the Pirin Mountain National Park. On the same day, activists from Za Zemiata protested against air pollution and wore gas masks in front of the National Palace of Culture in Sofia.

On Apr. 3, 2018: Citizens from the Sofia neighborhood Banishora shortly blocked a road in their neighborhood to protest against the moving of a center for drug addicts in their neighborhood. Later, the health inspectorate issued a statement this would not happen.

On Apr. 1, 2018: Citizens from the Sofia neighborhoods Gorna Banya and Ovcha Kupel organized a protest demanding to renovate and open again the public baths in both neighborhoods, which were also important historic buildings.

On Mar. 29, 2018: Citizens in Gorna Oryahovitsa gathered in front of the municipal building demanding that the local authorities should stop the planned construction for underpriviliged citizens, labelling them as 'parasites.'

On Mar. 26, 2018: Taxi drivers in Ruse protested demanding a fair trial for the murder of their colleague and the introduction of a panic button in taxi vehicles. The crime was committed a year ago in the village of Nikolovo, and two students were accused.
On Mar. 26, 2018: Citizens protested in Varna stating that Erdogan's presence on the territory of Bulgaria and the EU to be absolutely unacceptable and undesirable.

On Mar. 25, 2018: Citizens from the Sofia neighborhood Orlandovtsi protested against the passing of heavy trucks and cars with high speed on the roads of their neighborhood, close to schools and kindergartens.
On Mar. 24, 2018: Citizens in Pernik blocked a road towards Breznik protesting against the bad infrastructure and demanding better roads.
On Mar. 23, 2018: Citizens in Pernik blocked a road towards Kuystendil protesting against the bad infrastructure and demanding better roads.
On Mar. 23, 2018: Bulgarian truck drivers protested in Sofia against a new European directive which might result in losing their jobs due to additional expenses they have to pay.

On March 18, 2018 according to Unian a group of people with banners 'Stop Putin' gathered in front of the Russian Embassy in Sofia, Bulgaria, to protest against Russian elections held in the occupied Crimea.
On Mar. 17, 2018: Citizens in Burgas protested at the main square against air pollution and unpleasant smell in the city.
On Mar. 15, 2018: Employees from regional health inspectorate in Pazardzhik protested in front of their building demanding better working conditions and higher pay.
On Mar. 10: Citizens from the Vitosha neighborhood in Sofia protested against the poor infrastructure, lack of sidewalks and building noise.

On Mar. 10: Prison staff and court guards protested in front of the Council of Miniters, the Court of Justice and other governmental institutions in Sofia demanding better working conditions and higher salaries.

On Mar. 7, 2018: Citizens in Pernik protested against the local heating provider and the irregular heat supply to their homes. The protesters screamed 'Mafia' and 'Resign' at manager of the heat provider.
Police Forces of Bulgaria (2017-) Prison Guards; Labour Group (Bulgaria)
On Mar. 7, 2018: Prison and court staff protested outside the Court of Justice in Silistra demanding better working conditions and hiring of more staff.
Police Forces of Bulgaria (2017-) Prison Guards; Labour Group (Bulgaria)
On Mar. 7, 2018: Prison and court staff protested outside the Court of Justice in Vidin demanding better working conditions and higher pay.

On Mar.6, 2018: Citizens in Sofia protested in front of the Council of Ministers and urged Prime Minister Borisov to resign over a deal with the National Electric Company. The Bulgarian Socialist Party joined the protesters.
On Mar. 5, 2018: More than a hundred citizens gathered in Plovdiv for a second protest in solidarity with a doctor, suspected of the murder of a man from the ethnic Roma minority.
On Mar. 4, 2018: Citizens protested in front of a police station in Plovdiv in solidarity with a doctor who had been suspected of killing a male from the Roma ethnic minority.
On Mar. 1, 2018: General practitioner doctors in Sofia protested in front of the Ministry of Health demanding better working conditions and less administrative duties.

On Feb. 24, 2018: Prison officers and court guards gathered in a national protest at the Ministry of Justice demanding salary increase and better working conditions.
On Feb. 24, 2018: Tens of Kurds gathered outside the Turkish embassy in Sofia to protest against Turkey's military operation in Afrin.

On Feb. 24, 2018: Around 100 citizens protested in front of the Orthodox church in Varna against the Istanbul convention, carrying banners like 'Let's protect the Bulgarian family' and 'Let's protect our children.'
On Feb. 23, 2018: Court guards gathered in a protest at the Court of Justice in Haskovo demanding salary increase and better working conditions.

On Feb. 23, 2018: Prison guards gathered in a protest in Plovdiv demanding salary increase and better working conditions.
Police Forces of Bulgaria (2017-) Prison Guards
On Feb. 23, 2018: Prison guards gathered in a protest outside the Court of Justice in Sofia demanding salary increase and better working conditions.

On Feb. 22, 2018: Citizens protested outside the Council of Ministers in Sofia against government plans for construction of a ski lift in a protected area in the Pirin National park, accusing the government of catering to oligarhic interests.
On Feb. 20, 2018: Citizens from the Sofia neighborhoods Druzhba and Mladost protested otuside Parliament against changes in the municipal development plan and overdevelopment in Sofia.

On Feb. 17, 2018: A few thousand or hundreds of far-right nationalists from Bulgaria and other European countries, organized by the Bulgarian National Union, marched in Sofia to commemorate a local general who led a pro-Nazi organisation during World War II. A counterprotest against the far-right march was organized by the Bulgarian branch of the Antifa movement in Sofia, with the theme 'No Nazis on our Streets!' No violence was reported.
On Feb. 17, 2018: Citizens protested in Perushtitsa against the increase of garbage tax by 86%, which they deemed too high, considering that the garbage service was low-quality.
On Feb. 17, 2018: Citizens protested and blocked the traffic in the Sofia neighborhood Malashevtsi. They complained of the frequent passing of big load trucks in their neighborhood.

On Feb. 17, 2018: Citizens protested in Vidin for a fourth consecutive Saturday, insisting on the construction of a highway to connect Sofia and Vidin. The protesters complained of the bad condition of the roads, frequent accidents, and busy traffic.

On Feb. 16, 2018: Prison and judicial guard unions demonstrated at the Court of Justice in Sofia, insisting on a 20% increase in wages, a leveling of payments for harsh working conditions with those of police officers and solving staff shortage
On Feb. 16, 2018: Mothers protested in Dobrich insisting on the placement of videorecording devices in kindergartens and recruitment of more teachers and psychologists.

On Feb. 14, 2018: Parents protested outside the Council of Ministers in Sofia against closing the Nationalcardiac hospital, which was likely due to financial strain and lack of nurses. The hospital was the only institution which takes care of children with congenital heart problems.
On Feb. 12, 2018: Citizens from the Sofia neighborhood Mladost gathered to protest plans for construction in between their apartment buildings, which would limit the space and result in tree cutting.

On Feb. 11, 2018: About 40 parents of children from the kindergarten 'Prolet' protested in regards with violence against children in kindergartens, demanding videocameras to be installed and staff to be psychologically tested. The protest took place as a result of a kindergarten teacher who hit a child and his parents saw bruises on his face.
On Feb. 10, 2018: Parents in Burgas protested in relation to violence against children in kindergarten after the case of child abuse in kindergarten 'Brezichka.'

On Feb. 10, 2018: Citizens protested in Vidin, insisting on the construction of a highway to connect Sofia and Vidin. The protesters complained of the bad condition of the roads, frequent accidents, and busy traffic.
On Feb. 9, 2018: Citizens protested in Sofia against the construction of a building in the neighborhood Krasno selo, which was not announced to the people living in the vicinity.
On Feb. 9, 2018: Several citizens protested in front of the Council of Ministers building in Sofia against the Istanbul convention and its effect on the education of children about gender.

On Feb. 8, 2018: Ecoactivists staged a protest in the city center of Sofia demanding a change in the Pirin National Park management plan and the resignation of Minister of Environment and Water, Neno Dimov.

On Feb. 6, 2018: Dozens of citizen gathered close to the Council of Ministers building in Sofia to protest the construction of the protected areas of Pirin and denounce corruption practices around the issue.
On Feb. 5, 2018: Citizens in Ruse protested in front of the district administration building against persistent air pollution.

On Feb. 5, 2018: Citizens from three neighborhoods in Sofia protested against air pollution caused by the burning of old clothes and waste from the residents of the Vietnamese hostels and Fakulteta district.
On Feb. 5, 2018: Citizens gathered in front of the courthouse in Septemvri to support their mayor Marin Rachev and protest against allegations that he was involved in corruption.

On Feb. 5, 2018: Ecoactivists protested and demanded the resignation of Minister of Environment and Water, Neno Dimov. The protesters tried to sabotage his participation at a forum for ecological innovation, as some of them managed to enter the building of the event and chanted slogans against Dimov.

On Feb, 3, 2018: Citizens protested in front of the Council of Ministers in Sofia against ratification of the Istanbul convention. Protesters insisted the Bulgarian Orthodox church to organize a referendum on whether the convention should be signed or not.

On Feb. 3, 2018: Citizens protested in Vidin, insisting on the construction of a highway to connect Sofia and Vidin. The protesters complained of the bad condition of the roads, frequent accidents, and busy traffic.

On Jan. 29, 2018: Professionals from the field of education and social services protested in front of the House of Culture in Kardzhali against the 2018 municipal budget, which had a very small chunk planned for education and social services.
Police Forces of Bulgaria (2017-) Prison Guards
On Jan. 29, 2018: Prison guards protested demanding better pay and more job opportunities in Sofia.
Police Forces of Bulgaria (2017-) Prison Guards
On Jan. 29, 2018: Around 30 prison officials in Bobov Dol held an open-air meeting in Bobov Dol to protest their low salaries and increase the prison staff.
Police Forces of Bulgaria (2017-) Prison Guards
On Jan. 29, 2018: Over 100 prison officials in Lovech went on a protest demanding higher wages and increasing the number of prison guards in their understaffed prison.
Police Forces of Bulgaria (2017-) Prison Guards
On Jan. 29, 2018: Over 100 prison officials in Pleven went on a protest demanding higher wages and increasing the number of prison guards in their understaffed prison.
Police Forces of Bulgaria (2017-) Prison Guards
On Jan. 29, 2018: Prison officials in Varna went on a protest demanding higher wages and increasing the number of prison guards.

On Jan. 27, 2018: Residents of the Sofia neighborhood Gorublyane blocked the ring road in Sofia to protest against the urban park 'Iztok.' Protesters did not want the park to be built on the territory of their family houses.

On Jan. 27, 2018: Citizens protested in Vidin, insisting on the construction of a highway to connect Sofia and Vidin. The protesters complained of the bad condition of the roads, frequent accidents, and busy traffic.

On Jan. 25, 2018: Several thousand people and ecoactivists blocked the city center of Sofia to protest against construction in the Pirin Natinal Park. Protesters demanded the resingation of the Minister of Environment Neno Dimov and revealing the identity of the owner of the concession company that would operate in Pirin.

On Jan. 25, 2018: Dozens of parents and teachers in Vratsa protested against educational reforms regarding a newly prepared admission plan for the schools in the municipality of Vratsa, which would reduce the profiled classes and increase classes in the vocational schools.

On Jan. 22, 2018: Journalists and producers from the Bulgarian National Television protested in front of their building in Sofia against the new program director and former politician Emil Koshlukov. According to the protesters, Koshlukov censured content and had his own agenda about the morning weekday show. They also demanded Koshlukov to resign.

On Jan. 22, 2018: Seamstresses from a shoe factory in Dupnitsa protested as they had not received their wages for the months of December and January. The protesters called for the Labor Inspectorate and the Ombudsman to intervene.
On Jan. 19, 2018: Thousands of protesters gathered in Sofia for a fifth consecutive protest in defense of the Pirin Nature Park and demanded the resignation of Minister of Environment Dimov.

On Jan. 18, 2018: Several thousand Bulgarians protested in front of the Council of Ministers and the Presidency in Sofia against construction in the Pirin National Park. Protesters marched towards Orlov Bridge, where they blocked the traffic, and shouted 'Mafia' and 'Resign' at the government.

On Jan. 17, 2018: About 50 people protested in front of the Burgas municipality against air pollution in their city. Protesters said they did not believe in government data that pollution did not exist in Burgas.
On Jan. 14, 2018: Hundreds of Bulgarians marched in the city center of Sofia against construction on the territory of Pirin National Park.

On Jan. 11, 2018: Hundreds of police officers demonstrated in Sofia upon the first day of Bulgaria's EU presidency demanding an increase of their wages. On the same day, pensioners protested in Sofia demanding a rise in their minimum pension.
On Jan. 11, 2018: A small anti-NATO and anti-EU protester group gathered in Sofia upon the first day of Bulgaria's EU presidency. They burned the EU flag and shouted 'NATO out'.

On Jan. 11, 2018: Around 4,000-8,000 environmentalists demonstrated in Sofia upon the first day of Bulgaria's EU presidency against the government's decision to allow the expansion of a ski resort in the Pirin National Park. On the same day, around a thousand people staged a counter-protest in Sofia defending the government's decision.

On Jan. 11, 2018: About 100 people gathered in Sofia upon the first day of Bulgaria's EU presidency to protest against domestic violence and in support of the ratification of the Istanbul Convention, organized by the Alliance for Protection Against Gender-Based Violence and Animus Association Foundation.
